The relation of AGC and CN0 is relatively constant and known and when there is some abnormal situation, this relation will change. This relation can be seen on the chart so that the points appear on another place of the graphic. For example, if there is some RF interference the AGC and CN0 will decrease with respect to the values on nominal conditions. This chart shows points representing the average values of AGC and CN0 of all the satellites in view and every new point represents a new set of measurements.

CN0 depends on the elevation of the satellite so that a higher elevation usually involves a higher CN0. When that relation is not kept, some abnormal situation may be happening, such as multi-path or No-Line-Of-Sight.

This chart shows the error on the obtained positions of the modes that are selected, using the position obtained from Google as a reference. The computation of the position has to be started to see the information on this graph.

The ionosphere error depends on the elevation of the satellite, becoming smaller when the elevation gets bigger. In order to see the information on this graph, the positioning has to be started with some method that uses Iono-Free corrections.
The satellites under the selected elevation threshold will not be used on the computation.
If this option is enabled, two files will be created when a new computation is started. These files contain the measurements and the position logs and can be found on /Inari/Nmea/.
The satellites which signal has a CN0 lower than the selected threshold will not be used on the computation.
This option allows the user to enable or disable averaging and to select its duration.

Up to 5 modes can be selected at the same time to compute the position. The positions computed with the selected modes can be identified on the map by the different colors of the pins. A new mode can be created with the desired parameters.
* It is highly recommended to enable this option.
Please, select at least one positioning mode to compute the position
Please, select a band to create a new mode
Please, select at least one constellation to create a new mode"
A new mode needs a new name!
